When we say "The athlete might win gold and they might win silver," we are using the conjunction "and," which in logic means that both statements must be true.

In this case, the original statement allows for the possibility of winning either gold or silver, or both. The inferred statement asserts that both possibilities (winning gold and winning silver) are simultaneously possible.
